subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit considered problematic
msgSnippet: On Wed, 02 Apr 2003 10:00:05 -0000, javainsel  ... This is an uneducated statement -- why don t you spend some time learning what testing
messageBody:
On Wed, 02 Apr 2003 10:00:05 -0000, "javainsel" <javainsel@...>
said:
>
> > Violating pre- and postconditions is just a small subset of what
> can go
> > wrong in your code. Unit tests often test the interplay of two or
> three
> > methods, or even of several objects. You can't do this (effectively)
> > with embedded assertions.
> If you use Design by Contract then the implementation can be checked
> by
> the compiler to be valid or not. No JUnit needed. Focus on writing
> proper contracts instead of proper tests.

This is an uneducated statement -- why don't you spend some time learning
what testing is about before making these assumptions! The compiler is
actually on one kind of test.

> > Do you have a pointer?
> I don't know what you mean.

I think he meant do you have a POINT...

> > That's wrong, as others already stated.
> But how will you test a method which returns nothing?

As was said before, check the state the system is in before and after
calling the method. For example, return a DB connection to a Pool.
Check the DB pool to make sure the connection is there.

> > Asserts are even less a guarantee. Asserts need to be executed to be
> > effective - if you don't have external code invoking them in a well
> > directed manner, they will not be of any use until in the production
> > environment.
> In my following posting I favor Design by Contract instead of just
> using
> assert statements. I replied to myself. Read the thread when it
> appears.
> > If you really prefer this way, it wouldn't be too hard to include
> the
> > unit tests into your production code. Most people seem to prefer to
> > seperate the two.
> I prefer Design by Contract. Most people don't know that paradigma.

Many of us here are quite familiar with DBC -- again you make uneducated
assumptions.

> > Junit doesn't force you to develop test-driven at all.
> It suggests it strongy I think. Otherwise the synchronisation of code
> and test is endangered.

The ASSUMPTION you make here would be nice if it were true, however, it
is not. You obviously don't quite understand TDD/TFD. Go study some
more.

> > You might fear that it is. In practice, it doesn't seem to be that
> way.
> If you use TDD in its intended form than you lose time. Thats my
> opinion.

It would be better to back it up with real experience. I have done a lot
of development, using a lot of approaches and methodologies. I
personally have found myself to go MUCH faster with TDD. But I won't
take the time to belabor this point until you do more of your own
homework, or ask intelligent questions instead of throwing out these
ridiculously unfounded _opinions_!

> > minutes. There are even tools to automate this. My IDE shows me
> wether I
> > run the tests since the last code change, and an integration server
> > emails me if I broke a test nevertheless.
> Still much work. I prefer to concentrate on code and not on test
> quality.

I believe that most folks who understand unit testing would agree that
focusing on test quality IS focusing on "code" -- it sounds like you are
just LAZY!

> > So, did that help?
> Yes.
> Using Design by Contract is in a way a medium between implementation
> and
> tests. It is not as abstract as the implementation but not so
> concrete
> as the tests. Read my second thread (I replied to myself).

I could really flame you here, but I think I have said enough.

=jason
=jason
